text: We spoke about how we have two verbs for to be in Spanish, estar and ser, and we practiced with estar, which is the verb that we use for states.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we said that the word state is related to estar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Actually, it's like the same word.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What looks most different there between state and estar is that e that you get at the beginning of estar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But you will find this with words that start st, sp, s and consonant.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can't begin a word like this in Spanish, where you can in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So actually, you will find many words between English and Spanish that get like an extra e at the beginning in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In Spanish, is Espanol or Spain, which is Espana.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: There you have the o splitting of school to ue.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How do you think you might say strict if it's the same word in English and Spanish?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's the same word as well.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is the difference that we see between state and estar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we said that estar we use with what we will consider states of being.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, with what we consider characteristics of being, we will use ser.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we said that ser, all by itself, means being.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Un ser humano is a human being.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Here, humano is acting like an adjective.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But it could also be a noun.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But el ser humano, there it's an adjective.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I am from ser is soy.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So like estoy from estar, it ends oy.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: There are just four verbs in the whole Spanish language that use oy instead of o for I.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Voy, doy from dar, to give.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we said that student is estudiante.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you wanted to say I am a student.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It is, or she is, he is, you are, to usted.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We learned it already, but we didn't learn that it was from ser.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say it is possible?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now ser is more irregular than estar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It doesn't look like es is from ser.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then we had they are or you guys are.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we've got three of the versions now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can take son and we can work out the we form from son, working backwards.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now we said that working backwards means taking off the consonant that you know associates today, then putting on the ending that associates to we, for example.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So to go from son, they are, to we are, how do you think it will sound?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Which leaves one left, which is the you informal, which is eres.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And if you want to use the word for I?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And if you want to use the word for he?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what if you wanted to use the word for they?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: A nice way to remember they as well is you can make she plural and you will get the feminine they.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you guys is the plural of that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it's the plural of Usted, but it's not necessarily formal.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Only in some parts of Spain, which we will talk about later.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But everywhere else in the Spanish speaking world, this is just how you refer to you guys.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It doesn't sound formal anymore when it becomes plural.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say you guys are?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then we have we are?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Somos or nosotros somos, or if we were an all-female group.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then we have the you informal, which is eres, which is probably the weirdest form of these ones.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can relate it to es maybe.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say you are using the word for you?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What was the word for how?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now if I want to say how is he?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would I say using estar?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now if I want to ask you what is he like?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Maybe you tell me about your new boss or a new friend and I ask you what is he like or what is she like?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Am I referring to their state or to their characteristic?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would I ask how is he?
speaker: Speaker 1
